content.title: Metabolic Acidosis
content.summary: Primary acid-base disorder characterized by low serum bicarbonate and pH, classified by anion gap into high anion gap (MUDPILES) and normal anion gap (hyperchloremic) causes with distinct etiologies and treatments
key_points: Defined by HCO3- <22 mEq/L with pH <7.35
Calculate anion gap: Na - (Cl + HCO3); normal 8-12
High anion gap: MUDPILES (Methanol, Uremia, DKA, Propylene glycol, Isoniazid/Iron, Lactic acidosis, Ethylene glycol, Salicylates)
Normal anion gap: GI or renal HCO3- loss (diarrhea, RTA)
Calculate delta ratio: Δgap/ΔHCO3 to identify mixed disorders
Respiratory compensation: PaCO2 should equal last 2 digits of pH (Winter's formula)
Treatment: address underlying cause; bicarbonate controversial except pH <7.1

statement.text: Metabolic acidosis is a primary acid-base disturbance characterized by decreased serum bicarbonate (<22 mEq/L) and pH (<7.35). Classification by anion gap is essential: high anion gap acidosis results from accumulation of unmeasured anions (ketoacids, lactate, toxins), while normal anion gap (hyperchloremic) acidosis results from bicarbonate loss (GI or renal). The delta-delta ratio helps identify mixed disorders, and Winter's formula predicts appropriate respiratory compensation.
statement.formal: Metabolic Acidosis = HCO3- <22 mEq/L + pH <7.35; Anion Gap = Na - (Cl + HCO3); HAGMA vs NAGMA classification

explanation.intuition: The body maintains blood pH in a narrow range. When acid accumulates or base is lost, pH drops. The anion gap is a simple calculation that tells you whether unmeasured anions (like lactate or ketones) are piling up. A high anion gap means 'extra acid added'; a normal anion gap means 'bicarbonate lost and replaced with chloride.'
explanation.key_insight: Always calculate the anion gap—it immediately narrows the differential. Then calculate the delta ratio (change in gap / change in HCO3): ratio >2 suggests concurrent metabolic alkalosis; ratio <1 suggests concurrent non-gap acidosis. These calculations prevent missing mixed disorders.
explanation.technical_details: Henderson-Hasselbalch: pH = 6.1 + log([HCO3-] / (0.03 × PaCO2)). Respiratory compensation: expected PaCO2 = 1.5 × HCO3 + 8 ± 2 (Winter's formula). Anion gap correction for albumin: AG + 2.5 × (4 - albumin). Delta-delta calculation: if ΔHCO3 significantly less than Δgap, concomitant metabolic alkalosis; if ΔHCO3 significantly more than Δgap, concomitant non-gap acidosis.

definitions_glossary.metabolic_acidosis: Primary acid-base disorder with decreased bicarbonate and pH
definitions_glossary.anion_gap: Difference between measured cations and anions: Na - (Cl + HCO3)
definitions_glossary.lactic_acidosis: Accumulation of lactate from anaerobic metabolism or impaired clearance
definitions_glossary.diabetic_ketoacidosis: Metabolic acidosis from ketone body accumulation in insulin deficiency
definitions_glossary.renal_tubular_acidosis: Impaired renal acid excretion or bicarbonate reabsorption causing NAGMA
definitions_glossary.osmolar_gap: Difference between measured and calculated osmolality—elevated in toxic alcohol ingestion
definitions_glossary.winters_formula: Expected PaCO2 = 1.5 × HCO3 + 8 ± 2; validates respiratory compensation
definitions_glossary.uremic_acidosis: Metabolic acidosis from CKD due to reduced ammonium excretion
definitions_glossary.bicarbonate_therapy: IV sodium bicarbonate for severe acidosis (controversial except pH <7.1)

pathophysiology.mechanism: Metabolic acidosis results from: (1) increased acid production (ketoacids, lactate), (2) decreased acid excretion (renal failure), (3) bicarbonate loss (diarrhea, RTA), or (4) ingestion of acid or acid precursors (toxic alcohols). The body compensates through hyperventilation (Kussmaul breathing) to lower PaCO2 and partially restore pH.

causes.D: Diabetic ketoacidosis, Alcoholic ketoacidosis, Starvation ketosis
causes.I: Isoniazid, Iron, Inborn errors of metabolism
causes.L: Lactic acidosis (Type A: hypoxic; Type B: non-hypoxic)

causes.other: Acetazolamide, ammonium chloride, TPN, ureteral diversion

clinical_manifestations: Bone disease (chronic acidosis mobilizes calcium from bone)

anion_gap_calculation.correction: Add 2.5 for each 1 g/dL albumin below 4

nagma: Urine anion gap: UAG = UNa + UK - UCl
Positive UAG: renal cause (RTA)—kidney unable to excrete NH4+
Negative UAG: extrarenal (diarrhea)—kidney appropriately excreting NH4+

mixed_disorder_detection.delta_ratio: Δgap / ΔHCO3 (normal ~1); <1 = additional NAGMA; >2 = additional metabolic alkalosis

bicarbonate_therapy.indication: Controversial; generally reserved for pH <7.1 or HCO3 <8
bicarbonate_therapy.dose: HCO3 deficit = 0.5 × weight (kg) × (24 - measured HCO3); give half, recheck
bicarbonate_therapy.exceptions: RTA and some toxic ingestions may benefit from bicarbonate

dialysis.indication: Severe acidosis refractory to treatment, toxic alcohol ingestion, uremic acidosis
dialysis.modality: HD preferred for rapid correction; CRRT if unstable

respiratory_compensation_support.note: Do not intubate unless necessary—mechanical ventilation may not match spontaneous hyperventilation
respiratory_compensation_support.risk: If ventilated, set high minute ventilation to maintain compensation

definition.@value: Primary acid-base disorder characterized by decreased serum bicarbonate and pH, classified into high anion gap and normal anion gap subtypes with distinct etiologies

skos.scopeNote: Covers anion gap calculation, MUDPILES and NAGMA causes, delta-delta ratio, Winter's formula, and treatment principles
skos.example: A 28-year-old with type 1 diabetes presenting with nausea, vomiting, Kussmaul respirations, pH 7.18, HCO3 8, anion gap 24, positive ketones—classic diabetic ketoacidosis

learning_objectives: Calculate and interpret the anion gap
Apply MUDPILES mnemonic for high anion gap acidosis causes
Use urine anion gap to differentiate renal from GI causes of NAGMA
Calculate expected compensation using Winter's formula
Identify mixed acid-base disorders using delta-delta ratio
clinical_pearls: Always correct anion gap for albumin: AG + 2.5 × (4 - albumin)
Osmolar gap >10 with HAGMA: think toxic alcohols (methanol, ethylene glycol)
Lactic acidosis: Type A (tissue hypoxia) vs Type B (metformin, liver failure)
Urine anion gap: positive = kidney problem (RTA); negative = gut loss (diarrhea)
In DKA, betahydroxybutyrate is main ketone—nitroprusside test may miss it initially
Bicarbonate therapy in DKA may worsen CNS acidosis (CO2 crosses blood-brain barrier)

board_yield.nephrology_boards: Very High - RTA classification, advanced calculations

common_misconceptions: All patients with metabolic acidosis need bicarbonate (false—may be harmful in DKA, lactic acidosis)
Normal anion gap excludes serious disease (false—diarrhea, RTA can be severe)
Anion gap is always accurate (false—correct for albumin, consider unmeasured cations)
